awd_titl_txt: ECCS-CDS&E: High-performance computational framework for real-time phase retrieval X-Ray imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern science and technology increasingly rely on materials and devices utilizing unique properties of nanometer-scale composition. It is critical to be able to characterize such complex nanoscale configurations. A unique tool for characterization of nanoscale materials and devices is X-ray imaging, which can provide structural images with a high spatial and time resolution. In a typical X-ray imaging setup an X-ray source generates an X-ray beam that is scattered from the structure.  The scattered X-ray beam is captured by a camera, and the resulting picture is processed to reconstruct the actual structure configuration. Due to their short wavelength X-rays can penetrate the structure's volume thus enabling not only two-dimensional but also three-dimensional imaging. X-ray imaging typically requires a significant computational effort for image reconstruction and often the computational time is longer than the time for performing the experiment. This project aims at closing this gap by creating high-performance computational tools for real-time X-ray imaging. The created software is to serve a broad community of synchrotron scientists. The developments in nanoscale imaging are intended to have applications in areas ranging from condensed matter physics to biology and chemistry of single molecules. A close interdisciplinary research effort between a computational researcher and an expert in X-ray scattering and material physics will benefit graduate students and postdocs working in these fields, and is likely to result in new and unexpected discoveries.  

The goal of this research project is to create a high-performance computational framework for real-time X-ray imaging to be performed at X-ray scattering facilities. The X-ray imaging is to be accomplished using a new emerging three-dimensional X-ray imaging methodology called Coherent X-ray Diffractive Imaging (CXDI), which is based on computational phase-retrieval of the X-ray diffraction patterns. The proposed research includes algorithm and code implementation, practical application, and educational components. A set of algorithms for phase retrieval X-ray imaging are to be introduced, including methods for image representation and use of relevant constraints, methods for computing transformations between real to reciprocal spaces, and implementations on massively parallel computing systems. The research effort also introduces a virtual synchrotron framework utilizing computational methods to simulate experimental image reconstruction and provide required constraints, with magnetic nanostructures as a testbed. The developed computational framework is to be applied to real-time study of nanostructured materials and devices, such as nanoscale magnetic devices. The program integrates research and education by enhancing undergraduate and graduate courses on computational physics, micromagnetics and electromagnetics as well as providing graduate and undergraduate student training and contributing to diversity.

por.por_cntn:
The project aim was to overcome the challenges in three-dimensional coherent x-ray diffraction imaging (3D CXDI) by developing high-performance computational algorithms towards enabling real-time simulation and data analysis for X-ray imaging. A typical 3D CXDI scheme includes three steps: (1) an X-ray beam passes through a sample, which rotates thus changing its angle and diffraction patterns are recorded by a 2D pixelated detector, (2) a 3D reciprocal space image of the sample is constructed from the 2D images, (3) a phase retrieval algorithm is used to reconstruct the sample configuration, conventionally using repetitive 3D Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) algorithm. The phase retrieval algorithm requires multiple iterations of transforming the image space to the sample (physical) space and vice versa based on certain sample constraints. CXDI is a perfect example of how computations can assist experiment and device applications. CXDI is suited to rapidly obtain valuable information in three dimensions ultimately on atomic level in a variety of fields, such as tracking ionic diffusion in a working Li ion battery or measurements under applied magnetic or electric fields.

The project activities included two main components: (a) The development of high-performance 3D CXDI algorithms and (b) the development of high-performance codes for computing magnetization and electromagnetic field states for using the CXDI algorithm in numerically predicted samples and obtaining CXDI images that are expected in experiment.

In the development of CXDI techniques, the PIs introduced a novel 3D reconstruction CXDI algorithm, based on first reconstructing 2D slices and then combining them together into a 3D image. The algorithm has the following major achievements: (a) The reconstruction of 2D images is highly efficient and has a low memory consumption, (b) the 2D slices contain both amplitude and phase information, which results in highly accurate reconstructed 3D images, (c) the overall number of iterations can be significantly reduced, (d) the algorithm requires small memory and can be highly efficiently parallelized on GPUs, (e) the computational cost per iteration is also significantly reduced.

In the activities on the physics-based computations, the PIs developed efficient micromagnetic and electromagnetic solvers. The PIs introduced a formulation allowing computing the magnetization and electromagnetic field dynamics in complex nanomagnetic structures. The combined micromagnetic-electromagnetic solver is highly efficient and numerically stable. The PIs studied optically induced reversal and domain wall motion is magnetic films. The PIs also studied how optical excitations can drive the magnetization dynamics, including the ability to excite teraqhertz signals. 

High-performance 3D CXDI algorithms are expected to have impacts beyond the field of computational imaging. The ability to perform real-time CXDI impacts a broad community of synchrotron users who are in need in realistic, detailed, and tunable simulations of X-ray diffraction data. The algorithms impact many users employing CXDI by making the real-space reconstructions computationally robust and in real-time, speeding up data analysis by more than an order of magnitude. These developments in nanoscale imaging affect many applications in areas ranging from condensed matter physics and materials science to biology and chemistry of single molecules. The fast parallel and GPU-accelerated methods for image representation and real-reciprocal space transformation can be used in various other fields, such as image processing and various areas of computational physics.

The collaborative and interdisciplinary research effort between scientists specializing in computational approaches, experts in X-ray scattering and materials physics benefitted students involved in the project. The involved graduate students also benefitted from the opportunities of pursuing internships with the PI’s industrial partners.

3D CXDI provides information about objects and materials at nanoscale. This information has societal impacts beyond science in several ways. It contributes to technological developments, which, in turn, affect the society, e.g., by provides ways of communications and information storage. Additionally, the information provided by 3D CXDI extends our knowledge about materials and provides visualization, which assists in broadening knowledge in physics, chemistry, end engineering.
